Description: Premcor Refining Group, Inc., formerly known as Clark Refining and Marketing, Inc., agreed to pay a $6.25 million penalty to resolve claims that its Blue Island Refinery in Blue Island, Ill. violated five federal statutes: the Clean Water Act, the Clean Air Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act and the Emergency Planning, Community Right-To-Know Act and state of Illinois environmental laws and regulations. Premcor closed the refinery in January 2001.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: TPI Petroleum Inc. agreed to pay a $4 million civil penalty and spend $9.9 million on two community environmental projects in Alma and St. Louis, Mich., designed to clean up local waterways and promote the reuse of contaminated property in downtown Alma, under a settlement filed today in federal district court in Bay City, Mich.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2002 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: At part of a Clean Air Act settlement covering its petroleum refineries, Valero agreed to spend about $700 million to install improved emission controls. It also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $5.5 million and spend $5.5 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Info Source: Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2006 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency reached an agreement with Valero Energy Corp. providing for a $4.25 million penalty and $232 million in new and upgraded pollution controls at refineries in Tennessee, Ohio and Texas that were formerly owned by Premcor Inc. The state of Ohio and Memphis-Shelby County, Tenn. also joined in the consent decree and were to receive a portion of the civil penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Valero Refining-Texas, L.P. agreed to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Water Act stemming from an oil spill into the Corpus Christi Ship Channel by paying a civil penalty of $1.65 million and performing a supplemental environmental project costing about $300,000.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Agreed to pay a $500,000 civil penalty as part of the settlement of alleged pollution violations at its former Hartford refinery.

Premcor Refining Group (formerly Clark Refining and Marketing) agreed to pay $500,000 civil penalty in settlement of allegations its underground storage tanks (USTs) had contaminated soil and groundwater. It also agreed to pay $562,343 to remove 35 USTs.
Premcor Refining Group agreed to pay $192,622 for state costs incured in the cleanup and oversight of its former Blue Island refinery.
Premcor Refining Group (formerly Clark Refining and Marketing) agreed to pay $3.1 million in settlement of allegations of violating state environmental laws at its Blue Island refinery.
Notes: In addition to federal and state settlement same month

Description: Premcor Refining Group (formerly Clark Refining and Marketing) agreed to pay $2 million in settlement of allegations it violated the Clean Air Act when it made major modification to its Hartford facility to increase production without installing legally required pollution control equipment. $1.2 million went to the United States and $800,000 to Illinois. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-premcor-refining-group-inc

Valero agreed to pay $11 million -- consisting of a $5.5 million penalty and $5.5 million in spending on environmental projects -- to Colorado, Louisiana, New Jersey, Oklahoma and Texas as well as the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations. This was part of a larger $711 million settlement announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-valero
Valero agreed to pay $100,000 as part of the settlement of multistate litigation designed to curb the sale of tobacco products to minors.
Info Source: Massachusetts Attorney General Martha Coakley Announces Agreement with Valero to Curb Tobacco Sales to Minors, States News Service, April 9, 2010 (via Nexis).

Company: Valero Refining-New Orleans, LLC and Valero Services, Inc.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Clean Air Act violation. Penalty includes $2.85 million civil fine and $1.775 million for benzene reduction measures.
Premcor agreed to pay a $1,945,000 administrative penalty in settlement of allegations its refinery violated emissions regulations and failed to comply with permits.
Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: US DOJ issued a stipulated penalty demand on behalf of EPA & DE for LDAR violations. The total assessment was $350,000 and was split between the State and EPA. Superceded by agreement memorialized in 8/19/08 letter from US DOJ with reduced stip demand of $75k to be split by DE & EPA.
Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: Premcor agreed to pay a $425,000 penalty and a $30,000 penalty in settlement of alleged air emission and hazardous waste violations, and agreed to perform Environmental Improvement Projects consisting of: an estimated $4.5 million for improved burner management, $1.2 million for sulfur recovery, and $100,000 donations for environmental projects.
Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: EPA issued a stipulated penalty demand for tail gas incidents on 2/13/06 and 9/29-30/06 as well as acid gas flaring incidents on 6/13/06, 3/10/06, and 9/30/06. The total assessment was $39,179 and was split between the State and EPA.
Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: Premcor agreed to pay a $175,000 penalty, $9,384 in costs, $97,000 for environmental projects, and $103,000 for a conservation Easement on 12 acres of land, in settlement of alleged air and waste violations.
Agency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control
Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control

Description: Valero agreed to pay a $110,000 penalty plus $40,000 towards beneficial environmental projects in settlement of multiple unauthorized air emissions from its petroleum refinery and terminal.

Equilon Enterprises and Premcor agreed to pay $16 million for their part in a case in which residents of Hartford, Illinois sued oil and pipeline companies for creating an underground petroleum lake that released harmful vapors into the air. The court did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was split evenly between them.
